title: Teenage war hero who joined at 14 and spent 3 years in brutal Japanese PoW camp dies at 93
text:
UK Teenage war hero who joined at 14 and spent 3 years in brutal Japanese PoW camp dies at 93 Teenage war hero who joined at 14 and spent 3 years in brutal Japanese PoW camp dies at 93 A WAR hero who joined the Royal Navy when he was just a boy of 14 before being captured by the Japanese has died aged 93. PUBLISHED: 08:34, Tue, Feb 21, 2017 | UPDATED: 08:53, Tue, Feb 21, 2017 ARCHANT Harold lied about his age to get into the Navy at age just 14 
Harold Lock signed up to fight for King and Country in 1937 when the RN was still the world's most powerful navy after he lied about his age. 
War clouds were already gathering over Europe as Adolf Hitler armed Germany to the teeth. 
The Second World War broke out in September 1939 when the Germans invaded Poland as patriotic boy seaman Mr Lock did his training at HMS Ganges in Shotley, near Ipswich, Suffolk. Related articles SS-GB BBC make huge blunder after using WRONG spitfire in WW2 drama 
He was posted to new warship HMS Jupiter in 1940 when he was 17 and sent with a small Royal Navy task force to protect Australia from the Japanese fleet. 
The J-class destroyer sank the Japanese submarine I-60 on January 17, 1942 as Harold and his comrades saw action at the sharp end in the Far East. 
But just weeks later HMS Jupiter hit a mine on February 27 and quickly sank off the Indonesian coast after being ripped apart by a devastating explosion. ARCHANT Mr Lock was kept in a Japanese PoW camp for three years during the war 
Mr Lock managed to swim eight miles through shark-infested waters in a desperate bid to survive and escape. Death had become commonplace and we were getting like robots Harold Lock in The Forgotten Men 
But the exhausted sea salt was captured by Japanese soldiers as soon as he set foot on dry land. 
Mr Lock, from Sudbury, Suffolk, was locked up in a notoriously brutal PoW camp on the Indonesian island of Java and spent the rest of the war working as part of a hard labour gang. 
He toiled alongside thousands of fellow Allied prisoners building an airstrip on a tropical island, which the Japanese intended to use as a staging post for invading Australia. The Blitz 75th anniversary
